History (PGN): e4 e5 Nc3 c6 Nf3 d6 d4
Commentary: Why? This is the kind of move a player should never do. White menaces two times the e5 pawn, Black defends it only one time. So the result of this move is to lose a pawn. Here Black should have played 4. ... Nd7, getting back into the Hanham variation of Philidor defense which is a solid rather passive line.

Commentary: Unusually (for move 3) gameknot post-match analysis doesn't recognise this as 'book' (despite the fact this has been played as black by Carlsen, Kramnik, Anand, Aronian etc and over 100 times in games by the GMs Dreev, Postny & Drasko Gameknot gives an advantage of +0.71 and +0.02 to white after white & black's 3rd moves respectively - meaning that if white can hold this advantage then by the time it settles down, say around 10 moves in, you might expect around a +0.3 to +0.4 white advantage But Gameknot's engine doesn't seem to like white's subsequent moves with the advantage reducing slightly to move 6 and then more sharply after moves 7 & 8 although none of these are denoted 'inaccuracies'

History (PGN): e4 c6 d4 d5 Nc3 dxe4 Nxe4 Nf6 Nxf6+ exf6 Nf3 Bd6 Bd3 O-O O-O Re8 Re1 Be6 c4 h6 Be3 Nd7
Commentary: I felt that white could have played Nh4 one move earlier leaving that decision about whether to plant the Bishop on d2 or e3 until later but I felt that it's a cop out - I was pretty sure that Be3 has advantages over Bd2 (e.g. it allows Qd2 if I want to (Qc2 is still my plan A) so maybe there's an argument that Nh4 first might be better but I wanted to hold it back until next move....(I'd expected 11... Nd7 from black because if black did't play it now, then I don't know what else black would play, black isn't cramped if he plays it now but might get cramped if he leaves it for later? Nh4 helps to support the threat of d5 as black can no longer play Bg4 - d5 is the key threat for white to exploit black's cramped position and difficult communication between pieces or even potentially force simplification into a position where white has a passed d pawn (isolated makes it a target when lots of pieces are on the board but in an endgame it can become a key strategic benefit for white)

Black is a pawn down, doesn't control the center, the King is in center (but ready to eventually castle queenside), has his queen bad placed and developed the Queen's knight on d7. Here the advantadge is big and White should not lose time!

Let me start with a disclaimer: this is my first annotated game and I have no idea if a game like this one is even interesting for the majority of players here. Still, I enjoyed this game myself as it features a non-standard opening and to me demonstrates the danger of developing your queen too early.

History (PGN): Nf3 c5 c4 Nc6 Nc3 Nd4 Nxd4 cxd4 Ne4 e5 d3 Nf6
Commentary: There is an expression that says that to take is a mistake. Many people like to trade pieces automatically without thinking about it. This sometimes throws me off because it is not always true. To take is a mistake when the capture improves the opponent's position. That would appear to be the case here because Black gets to develop his queen, but White rids himself of his problem piece. (Exchanges in chess are often a trade-off between good and bad, like giving up the bishop pair to double pawns.)

It really invites my knight to perch in d5 if I can get away with it, but that's a potential opportunity to explore later.

Commentary: So I'm down a pawn entering the middle game - the middle is torn asunder and he has slightly more of a command of it with his knights. General plan of attack is I need his pawn on c6 to stay competitive. Similarly I think his best plan is to target c7 via moves like Bf4, Ne4 and Rc1. Ultimately I like my bishop pair with the open board but it'll be hard to limit his knights. Qe8 seems challenges the pawn but Nd4 defends and challenges my bishop straight away. Projected line of 14. ... Qe8 15. Nd4 Nd5 16. Re1 Nxc3 17. bxc3 seems okay but doesn't terribly get me closer to my objectives. Qb1 seizes an open column and lets tickle a potential target on b2.

History (PGN): e4 c6 Bc4
Commentary: Every time I look at a Hillbilly attack game, I see it backfiring against those who try it. Except maybe in bullet, when played by an IM, feels like the Black side always get some kind of a small advantage from the opening. Of course for our little levels, nothing is given, we make too many mistakes even when we play an opening for years, and I don't know this one yet, so it was exciting to try against a higher rated player than myself and learn what happens here.

Commentary: I considered many moves for my opponent and could not find any great ones myself. The best one seemed to be the forced trade of queens, but even it led to some advantage because of the weakness of the light squares and my knight and rook either close enough to deliver a famous mate, after some precautionary measures with pawns, or else strong enough to secure the g pawn from threatening to promote itself. For this specific variation, that I also considered, I really wanted to try the knight:g3, if the rook is taken its a mate, but of course, the rook doesn't have to be taken. All kinds of complexities, maybe winning. But then it occurred to me. Can be simpler. A fork is still possible even now, and then, the queen can actually be blocked from delivering any perpetuals. Now that was of course the clear choice now.

Commentary: The plays the Winawer Variation: 3...Bb4 This variation, named after Szymon Winawer was pioneered by Nimzowitsch and Botvinnik, is one of the main systems in the French, due chiefly to the latter's efforts in the 1940s, becoming the most often seen rejoinder to 3.Nc3, though in the 1980s, the Classical Variation with 3...Nf6 began a revival, and has since become more popular. 3... Bb4 pins the knight on c3, forcing White to resolve the central tension.

History (PGN): e4 c5 Nf3 g6 d4 cxd4 Nxd4 Bg7
Commentary: I opt for a Maroczy Bind formation. The Maróczy Bind (Hungarian: [ˈmɒroːt͡si]) is a pawn formation in chess, named after the Hungarian grandmaster Géza Maróczy and primarily played against the Sicilian Defence and sometimes played against the King's Indian Defence. It is characterised by white pawns on c4 and e4, with White's d-pawn having been exchanged for Black's c-pawn. White's c- and e-pawns control the d5-square, making it difficult for Black to free their position with ...d5; Black often settles for the less active ...d6 instead. Black often employs a Hedgehog formation against the Bind. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mar%C3%B3czy_Bind

Commentary: Exchanges simplify life. A few rules on exchanges according to evilgm... First, don't exchange just because you can't think of another move (note, I am not suggesting that is the case here, just saying). Second, you want to try and create an advantage with an exchange. Doing something unexpected or out of sequence can sometimes induce a player to blink. Identify those opportunities before you exchange. Third, you need pieces to mount an attack (or defend), so don't get rid of a lot of pieces or you won't have anything with which you can attack. I like Nf5 as an option to consider here.

Commentary: I was looking to get in …Bg4, pinning White’s e2-knight, which he might have had some difficulty unpinning, and I was prepared to meet 12.f3 with 12.… exf3 13.Bxf3 Rxe3, and then if 14.Nxd5 Nxd5 15.Bxd5 Bb5 or 14.Bxd5 Bg4. White beats me to the punch in a different way, however, and I must now decide where to park my dark-square bishop. Maintaining the potential to pin the other knight has its appeal but is rather easily addressed, so the choice is between c7 (via a5) and d6. I believe I can adequately defend my backward d-pawn with minor pieces, so I choose the latter, thinking the c-file could turn out to be an avenue for attack.

History (PGN): e4 c5 Nf3 e6 d4 cxd4 Nxd4 a6 Bd3 Nf6 O-O h6 e5 Nd5 Re1 Nc6 Nxc6 dxc6 c4 Nb4 Be4 a5
Commentary: I did just wonder about 12.Qxd8+ With queens off not being able to castle wouldn't usually be an issue but could white have tied up black's development even more with the king in the middle? That said, black just seems to be getting in a tangle now, why relieve the pain? If for instance 12.....a4(thematically consistent with having played a5 but any queenside threat from balck at this stage is just barking into the wind while underdeveloped and king potentially vulnerable) then 13 Be3 leaves white a small advantage- Black is cramped, underdeveloped, white can be first to use the d-file, looks like black HAS to castle into a white K-side expansion or else try to find some safety like Kf8 but needs to be careful to avoid being a sitting duck White needs to play Nc3 and R(probably a) d1 to complete development and then begin the press with Qg3, f4, Rd6 which are all thematic eg 13. Be3 Ra5 14. Qg3 g6 15. a3 Na6 16. Nc3 Qc7 17. Rad1 Nc5 18. Bc2 Bg7 19. f4 O-O 20. Rd6 d6 square looks important strategically - should white look to position rook or knight or rook there - in event that black does the exchange on e4, then white posting N on d6 looks like a dagger in black's territorial heart- 13. Be3 Qc7 14. a3 Na6 15. Nc3 Nc5 16. Rad1 Nxe4 17. Nxe4 Be7 18. Qg3 Kf8 19. Nd6 The decision for white is whether to try to keep the light square bishop exerting pressure on b1-h7 diagonal Or whetehr to let black lose more tempi exchanging with Nxe4, Nxe4 and then really squeeze black in a closed position - my preference at this stage is the latter but either one can be good maybe black should play 12.....Qc7 I quite like an immediate Qg3 12. Qf3 Qc7 13. Qg3 g6 14. Nc3 Bg7 15. f4 Qb6+ 16. Be3 c5 17. a3 but need to look at this line some more remember, withn Sicilian, if black weathers the storm, black tends to fight back....

History (PGN): e4 d5 exd5 Qxd5 Nc3 Qa5 Bc4 Nf6 d4 Nc6 a3 g6 h3 Nxd4 Qxd4 Bg7 Bxf7+ Kxf7 Nf3
Commentary: This is the "knight to the rim" move that prompted me to annotate this game. The black knight wasn't under threat. White's c knight could attack it, but black still has a pawn, bishop, and king backup. The purpose of this move was to launch a surprise attack on the queen. If white ignores this threat she falls. But before you push a piece you should know where it will go. In this case the white queen must guard the c knight, or black plays BxNc3+ and white ends up losing at least the knight. if white interposes the bishop black gets the poison pawn (b2) for free too. If white plays bxBc3 black plays QxNc3+ and snags Ra1. So white must be careful about where to place the queen.

Commentary: White is ahead in development, and I was hesitating between e6 and e5. After the game, my opponent told me that e6 is the best theoretical reply, and during the game I also knew that e6 was better, especially that it controls d5 against Nd5 and keeps my Bc6 alive (for "whom" I've spent 1 tempi) But knowing the player I was playing against, I did not accept giving two tempis of development gap. So I've played e5 with tempi, contradicting the previous plan I've made with Bd7.

My main problem is panicking and making a move too fast without observing all the pieces on the board first and thinking ahead. Hello everyone and welcome to my 2nd annotation on GameKnot! Today we have yours truly up against a much higher rated opponent in JotheBlackQueen. I hope what follows is an interesting analysis as I try to explain my thought process as things develop in this very interesting game. So we have Jo opening up with the Reti Opening 1.Nf3 It's not one I see very often it must be said.

Commentary: This was a good response. If black attacks the knight with Qa6, white can defend with c3. If black follows with b5, white plays the e pawn. Black can't take the knight without sacrificing the queen, and white regains momentum.

I am sure it's playable, though as a personal preference, I would have liked to get my light squared bishop out first. But maybe my opponent thought that that variation, with bishop on d6, pawn on c3 is overplayed. I guess I cannot disagree, I do see it a lot even on our lesser levels.
